item.title: [GROOVY-5051] 'this' uses in a superclass is treated as subclass, preventing acces to private members
item.description:
The original thread: http://groovy.329449.n5.nabble.com/Currying-an-instance-method-exception-with-modifier-private-td4849071.html

The following code explains the issue:

class Base {

    private __value(arg) { println "$arg" } // <<< here
    def value = this.&__value.curry('value')
    def extend() {
        def tmp = this.&__value.curry('extend')
        tmp()
    }
}

class Sub extends Base {

    def test() {
        value()
        extend()
    }
}

new Sub().test()

The only change it needs is to change the private to def / protected in the line marked with '// <<<'.

Similar Java code behaves correctly:

class Base {

	private int get() {
		return 17;
	}

	int a = this.get(); // <<< here

	public void test() {
		System.out.println(a);
	}
}

public class Sub extends Base {

	public static void main(String[] args) {
		new Sub().test();
	}
}

When Sub is instantiated, the call to the private get() is done in the superclass, who can access it.

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
You can use a combination of the declaring class and curry for a workaround since Groovy 3:

class Base {
    private __value(arg) { println arg }
    def value = Base.&__value.curry(this,'value')
    def extend() {
        def tmp = Base.&__value.curry(this,'extend')
        tmp()
    }
}
